messageBody:
Yeah... migrating to JUnit4 with a bunch of existing JUnit3 tests is
troublesome. However if you've been using Suites all along it's not
that hard.



What we've done is collected all of the old JUnit3 Suites into an file
named OldTestSuite.java.



It looks like this (left out imports)



@RunWith(AllTests.class)

public class OldTestSuite {

public static Test suite() {

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

suite.addTest(<ClassName>.suite());

suite.addTest(<ClassName>.suite());

.....

return suite;

}

}



Then our new JUnit4 test suite looks like this (left out imports)



@RunWith(Suite.class)

@...({

OldTestSuite.class,

.....

})

public class FullTestSuite {

//annotations only

}



I think this is documented a little differently here...
http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_1 item 4. But they
work the same... I think. Please correct me if I'm wrong.



Big Mike

That helped. I set my ant home to 1.7 and it worked. Is these a doc/link
which mentions how to migrate old JUnit test to the newer syntax.

How can I have a mix of older style (Pre Junit 4.0 Tests) and new style
(with annotations) tests in one class. When I run them, it seems to be
running only the old style tests. I was able to run all of them only by
removing "extends TestCase" and using "@Test" annotation for everything.
Is the the only way or are there other ways.

regards,
Suresh

I think that Ant 1.6.5 can't run JUnit 4 Tests without an Adapter.

Ant 1.7.0 is the first JUnit 4-aware release, if I remember correctly.
